manuscript.title: Hediyyetü's-Sü'lûk fî Şerhi Tuhfeti'l-Mülûk (هدية السلوك في شرح تحفة الملوك)
manuscript.author: Ebü'l-Leys Muharrem b. Muhammed b. Ârif ez-Zilî es-Sivâsî el-Kastamûnî el-Halvetî el-Hanefî (d. 1000/1592)
manuscript.notes: Undated. Arabic text in nastaʿlīq (nestalik) script — unusual for a fiqh commentary, where naskh is far more common; nastaʿlīq use here may reflect a Persian cultural context or a post-16th-century Ottoman scholarly milieu. Author d. AH 1000 / CE 1592 provides a terminus post quem. Söz başları (section incipits) and matlablar (chapter headings) in red; cekveli yaldız zencirekli (gold chain-border ruling). Binding: miklepli kırmızı meşin (flap-binding in red leather), with matching mahfaza (slipcase) of the same description — a luxury binding feature. Cataloguer: Zahide Kutlay.

paper_decoration.summary: The YEK kagit_ozellikleri field reads 'Üzüm salkımı taç filigranli, sarı boyalı' — identical to manisa_4620-1 (same cataloguer, same formula), indicating yellow-dyed (sarı boyalı) paper with a bunch-of-grapes crown watermark. Visual examination of p005 shows a yellow/warm tone consistent with sarı boyalı. The same color calibration caveat applies as for manisa_4620-1. The binding is notably more luxurious than the paper decoration would suggest: yaldız zencirekli (gold chain-border) framing system on the binding and a dedicated mahfaza (slipcase), indicating a higher-status commission than the plain fiqh manuscripts at adjacent shelfmarks. The identical paper description across manisa_4620-1 and manisa_4633 (same cataloguer, same formula) strengthens the case that 'sarı boyalı' reflects genuine intentional dyeing rather than cataloguing error.

terms_used.english: Yellow-dyed paper: manuscript paper dyed yellow before writing. The Ottoman term 'sarı boyalı' is a specific cataloguing descriptor distinguishing intentional yellow dyeing from the general 'mülevven' (colored). Identified here and in the adjacent manisa_4620-1 record; both share the same cataloguer (Zahide Kutlay) and identical paper formula, which may indicate a cluster of yellow-dyed manuscripts in the Manisa collection.

Zencirek (chain border): a narrow ornamental band composed of repeating interlinked ring or loop motifs in gold. Applied to page edges, calligraphy panels, and binding edges; in this manuscript, the yaldız zencirekli (gold chain-border) appears as a binding decoration feature rather than as page-level paper decoration.

Mahfaza: a protective slipcase for a manuscript volume, often constructed to match the binding in materials and decoration. A yaldız zencirekli red leather mahfaza accompanying this manuscript is a luxury feature indicating a relatively high-status commission.

Sharḥ: a commentary or explanation on an earlier text; in the context of Islamic jurisprudence, a sharḥ expands and explicates an earlier compendium (here: Tuhfat al-Mulūk by al-Rāzī al-Ḥanafī, d. 666/1268). The Ḥanafī sharḥ genre was one of the most widely copied text genres in Ottoman manuscript production.

bibliography.relevance: Covers paper production and trade in the Islamic world, including European watermarked papers; relevant to the üzüm salkımı taç filigranı (bunch-of-grapes crown watermark) and the use of European paper stocks in late Ottoman manuscript production.

suggested_collections.reason: Home collection; the adjacent manisa_4620-1 shares an identical paper description (sarı boyalı, same watermark, same cataloguer), making it the most direct comparandum. Systematic examination of the Manisa collection for yellow-dyed papers may reveal a local cluster.

Holds numerous Ḥanafī fiqh commentary manuscripts (sharḥ on Tuhfat al-Mulūk and related texts) and yaldız zencirekli leather bindings for comparison; also provides codicological comparanda for nastaʿlīq fiqh manuscripts.

provenance.notes: Held in the Manisa İl Halk Kütüphanesi (Manisa Provincial Public Library), western Anatolia, Turkey. Catalogued by Zahide Kutlay. Undated; author's death date (AH 1000 / CE 1592) provides terminus post quem. No waqf or donor information recorded. The yaldız zencirekli red leather binding with matching mahfaza suggests a relatively high-status commission, possibly for a wealthy madrasa or private patron in the Manisa region. Note: identical paper description to manisa_4620-1 (same cataloguer, same formula: 'Üzüm salkımı taç filigranli, sarı boyalı'), suggesting a cluster of yellow-dyed manuscripts processed by the same cataloguer, potentially from the same original library or acquisition lot.
